text: I personally can’t stand humble bragging of ‘verified’ blue ticked ppl talking about their follower count, network and reach. Talk is cheap is a die hard motto. Talk less about yourself. Talk more about the value you delivered to someone else today. Measure yourself in the success of others. Otherwise everything you say is hot air.

text:
Not sure if this is the right channel..so happy to cross post this in the right channel.

Marketing orgs are perhaps the most complex thing ever in a company. :grimacing: 
Or maybe because I am a complete newbie. But there is so much under the marketing gamut! 

From what I see in our org, we need to run following programs:

• Content - long tail seo + some pillar categories
• Product marketing - better communicate about our product features etc
• Paid Ads
• Influencer & referral partnerships
• Integration partner programs
• MSP program
• Website CRO 
• Email nurture for leads and churn
• Outbound for large accounts
• Social media engagement
We serve from prosumer ($10 per month) to midmarket (~5k per month) customers. Large majority is $10 per month segment. Scale - over 15K customers. 

The easy answer for org design in - get head of marketing but I'd love to dig in and get some of the programs started to build out an org.

Curious to hear (assuming it won't be sensitive info as it can be pieced from LinkedIn), what your marketing org structure looks like?

Also, if someone has spent time designing marketing orgs - I'd love some 1:1 time! 

Sorry if this is too loaded a question. :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
I don't think you would need all the laundry list of functions you have described. For example, for $10/month customers (you haven't mentioned the LTV), paid is not the best channel. You should build your marketing org around top 2-3 channels which have historically yielded the best ROI and outsource the rest if at all you need them.
In terms of structure, under the CMO you have 5 broad functional managers: demand gen and branding (housing content, organic and social media), performance marketing (housing paid ads across channels and influencer partnerships), product marketing (housing strategy and sales enablement, this can be further sub-divided by product line or regions based on how rest of your org is structured), growth (housing experiments and CRO) and ops (housing ops, processes and analytics. Even email marketing). This is very broad. People like to mix it up based on goals. One functional manager for each goal and then individual executives or managers for each sub-function. Some people also like to have a vertical content, design and marketing engineering function and treat them like a separate function where different teams can give them request.

elements.text:

In terms of structure, under the CMO you have 5 broad functional managers: demand gen and branding (housing content, organic and social media), performance marketing (housing paid ads across channels and influencer partnerships), product marketing (housing strategy and sales enablement, this can be further sub-divided by product line or regions based on how rest of your org is structured), growth (housing experiments and CRO) and ops (housing ops, processes and analytics. Even email marketing). This is very broad. People like to mix it up based on goals. One functional manager for each goal and then individual executives or managers for each sub-function. Some people also like to have a vertical content, design and marketing engineering function and treat them like a separate function where different teams can give them request.

text: Hey <@U0322F1V64C> im someone who favours having resources in-house, especially the strategic & subject matter experts. These guys should be able to create direction & briefs for the agency. No agency will drive your marketing for you unless you have someone who can manage them. Happy to catch up in Gurgaon and discuss marketing.
